elements.content: Luminescent silver­(I) halogenido coordination polymers [Ag2X2(PPh3)2(bpy)] n (X = I, Br, Cl) have been prepared. The iodido and bromido complexes exhibit strong blue phosphorescence assignable to the 3π–π*-excited-state of bpy, whereas the chlorido complex shows luminescence thermochromism due to the π–π*-state of bpy and charge transfer from the {Ag2Cl2} core to the bpy π*-orbital. Taking advantage of their structural similarities, we prepared a series of mixed-halogenido silver­(I) complexes [Ag2(X x X′(1–x))2(PPh3)2(bpy)] n (X, X′ = I, Br, Cl) at varying molar fractions as solid solutions. The mixed-halogenido complexes are as strongly luminescent as their parent complexes. The detailed study of their structure and emissive properties revealed smooth energy migration between the luminescent units and modification of the luminescence properties based on the planarity of bpy.
elements.clean_text: Luminescent silver(I) halogenido coordination polymers [Ag2X2(PPh3)2(bpy)] n  (X = I, Br, Cl) have been prepared. The iodido and bromido complexes exhibit strong blue phosphorescence assignable to the 3π-π*-excited-state of bpy, whereas the chlorido complex shows luminescence thermochromism due to the π-π*-state of bpy and charge transfer from the {Ag2Cl2} core to the bpy π*-orbital. Taking advantage of their structural similarities, we prepared a series of mixed-halogenido silver(I) complexes [Ag2(X x X'(1-x))2(PPh3)2(bpy)] n  (X, X' = I, Br, Cl) at varying molar fractions as solid solutions. The mixed-halogenido complexes are as strongly luminescent as their parent complexes. The detailed study of their structure and emissive properties revealed smooth energy migration between the luminescent units and modification of the luminescence properties based on the planarity of bpy.

elements.content: The luminescence properties of silver­(I) coordination polymers [Ag2X2(PPh3)2}­(bpy)] n (X = I, Br, Cl) are rationalized, and strongly luminescent mixed-halogenido coordination polymers [Ag2(X x X′(1−x))2(PPh3)2}­(bpy)] n (X, X′ = I, Br, Cl) have been prepared. The planarity of bridging bpy, essential for color emission, is determined by the ratio of halogenido ligands through crystal packing effects.

The planarity of bridging bpy, essential for color emission, is determined by the ratio of halogenido ligands through crystal packing effects.

elements.content: Monovalent Group 11 metal ions afford luminescent materials with a wide variety of ligands. Extensive studies on strongly luminescent gold­(I) and copper­(I) complexes bearing ligands such as N-donors, phosphines, acetylides, cyanides, S-donors, and carbenes have been reported. Luminescent silver­(I) complexes with these ligands have also been reported more recently. The excited states associated with the photoemission of these d10 complexes include simple metal-centered, metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT), and ligand-centered transitions. It is known that direct and indirect metal–metal interactions are often observed in these d10 complexes and play important roles on the characteristic photoemissive properties, such as thermochromic luminescence, thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF), and stimulus-responsive luminescence.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Monovalent Group 11 metal ions afford luminescent materials with a wide variety of ligands. Extensive studies on strongly luminescent gold(I) and copper(I) complexes bearing ligands such as N-donors, phosphines, acetylides, cyanides, S-donors, and carbenes have been reported. Luminescent silver(I) complexes with these ligands have also been reported more recently. The excited states associated with the photoemission of these d10 complexes include simple metal-centered, metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT), and ligand-centered transitions. It is known that direct and indirect metal-metal interactions are often observed in these d10 complexes and play important roles on the characteristic photoemissive properties, such as thermochromic luminescence, thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF), and stimulus-responsive luminescence.

elements.content: We have previously reported a series of copper­(I) halogenido complexes [Cu2(μ-X)2(PPh3)2(L) n ] (X: Cl, Br, I) composed of a halogenido-bridged dimeric core {Cu2(μ-X)2} with PPh3 and N-heteroaromatic ligand L. These dicopper­(I) complexes are of discrete molecular type when L is a monodentate N-heteroaromatic ligand. The complexes show strong emission in the solid state associated with a transition from the {Cu2(μ-X)2} core to the ligand π*-orbital. The emission energies can be tuned to cover the entire visible region using N-heteroaromatic ligands with different π*-levels. By using a bridging ligand such as 4,4′-bipyridine (bpy), a coordination polymer [Cu2(μ-I)2(PPh3)2(μ-bpy)] n was obtained exhibiting strong emission (emission maximum (λmax): 530 nm, quantum yield (ϕ): 0.65) at room temperature in the solid state. We also prepared the silver­(I) congener [Ag2(μ-I)2(PPh3)2(μ-bpy)] n , which is also strongly luminescent with λmax = 450 nm and ϕ = 0.72. Subsequently, on the basis of the isomorphology of the crystals of copper­(I) and silver­(I) complexes, we successfully prepared a series of mixed-metallic Cu–Ag complexes [{(Cu x Ag(1–x))2I2(PPh3)2}­(μ-bpy)] (x = 0–1), all of which are strongly luminescent with emission maxima at 450 nm (Ag sites), 530 nm (Cu sites), or both. It was interesting to observe that even the polymer with a copper fraction as low as 0.005 showed strong emission from the copper sites. This emission behavior demonstrates that rapid energy migration takes place between the luminescent Cu and Ag units and that highly efficient antenna effects exist in the mixed-metallic coordination polymers, where the silver and copper units work as donors and acceptors, respectively. We have also reported a series of isomorphous crystals of mixed bridging-ligand complexes, [Cu2I2(PPh3)2(μ-bpa)(1–x)(μ-bpe) x ] n , where bpa and bpe are bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethane and bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethylene, respectively. The bpa homobridged polymer showed much stronger emission compared to the bpe counterpart (quantum yields of 0.094 and 0.006 at room temperature, respectively). The mixed-bridged complex with a bpe fraction as low as 0.004 showed characteristic emission from the bpe sites, whereas that from the bpa sites was largely quenched. Thus, an antenna effect where the bpa sites act as donors is evident. These studies showed that coordination polymers of dimeric cores [M2(μ-X)2(PPh3)2] bridged by 4,4′-bipyridine-type ligands tend to form a series of either mixed-metal or mixed-ligand complexes based on crystal isomorphology, showing rapid photoenergy transfer along the polymer chain.

These dicopper(I) complexes are of discrete molecular type when L is a monodentate N-heteroaromatic ligand. elements.content: Herein, we focus on the halogenido ions in the M2(μ-X)2 (X = Cl, Br, I) core as another important component of these coordination polymers. In this paper, we report the luminescence properties of three halogenido-bridged silver­(I) complexes, [Ag2X2(PPh3)2(bpy)] (X = I, Br, Cl), and the synthesis and properties of mixed-halogenido complexes [{Ag2(X x X′(1–x))2(PPh3)2}­(bpy)] n (X, X′ = I, Br, Cl). The bromido complex is isomorphous to the iodido complex, and both display similar emission features, whereas the chlorido complex has a different structure and exhibits luminescence thermochromism. The mixed-halogenido complexes are isomorphous to either the iodido or chlorido complex. Their luminescence properties reflect their different structural motifs.

The bromido complex is isomorphous to the iodido complex, and both display similar emission features, whereas the chlorido complex has a different structure and exhibits luminescence thermochromism. The mixed-halogenido complexes are isomorphous to either the iodido or chlorido complex. Their luminescence properties reflect their different structural motifs.

elements.content: Silver iodide was purchased from Kojima Chemicals Co. Silver bromide and silver chloride were purchased from Junsei Chemicals Co. Organic solvents and bpy were purchased from Wako. The iodido and bromido complexes were prepared as described in our previous reports. The chlorido complex was prepared by a modified method following the report by Song et al.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Silver iodide was purchased from Kojima Chemicals Co. Silver bromide and silver chloride were purchased from Junsei Chemicals Co. Organic solvents and bpy were purchased from Wako. The iodido and bromido complexes were prepared as described in our previous reports. The chlorido complex was prepared by a modified method following the report by Song et al.

elements.content: AgCl (4.7 mg, 0.033 mmol) and PPh3 (17.5 mg, 0.066 mmol) were dissolved in a solvent mixture of CH2Cl2/DMF (2 mL, 2 mL), to which was added a CH3CN solution of bpy (1.0 mL, 18 mg, 0.12 mmol). After a few days, the solution afforded colorless crystals. Yield: 5.4 mg (17%). Anal. calcd for [{Ag2Cl2(PPh3)2}­(bpy)] n : C, 57.11; H, 3.96; N, 2.90. Found: C, 56.87; H, 4.01; N, 2.85.

elements.content: A CH3CN/DMF (1:4) mixed solution containing AgI (1.10 mmol/L) and PPh3 (2.21 mmol/L) was prepared. A CH3CN/DMF (1:4) mixed solution containing AgBr (1.66 mmol/L) and PPh3 (3.31 mmol/L) was prepared. From two stock solutions, specific amounts were taken and mixed as shown in Table S1, to make the total amount of AgX 0.033 mmol and the Br fraction 0.1, 0.3, 0.5, 0.7, and 0.9 in each solution. To each solution was added a CH3CN solution of bpy (0.115 mmol, 1.0 mL). After a few days, the solution afforded homogeneous colorless crystals. The molar fraction of Br (x) in the compound was determined by elemental analysis.

elements.content: Single crystals of [{Ag2(X(1–x)X′ x )­(PPh3)2}­(bpy)] n ((X, X′): (I, Br), (Br, Cl), (I, Cl)) suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained as described above except for [Ag2(I0.05Cl0.95)2(PPh3)2}­(bpy)] n . The selected crystals were mounted on loops. Measurements were performed on a Mercury CCD area detector coupled to a Rigaku AFC-8S diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation at −120 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Analysis

Single crystals of [{Ag2(X(1-x)X' x )(PPh3)2}(bpy)] n  ((X, X'): (I, Br), (Br, Cl), (I, Cl)) suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained as described above except for [Ag2(I0.05Cl0.95)2(PPh3)2}(bpy)] n . The selected crystals were mounted on loops. Measurements were performed on a Mercury CCD area detector coupled to a Rigaku AFC-8S diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation at -120 °C.

elements.content: Although the structures of the bromido and chlorido complexes [{Ag2X2(PPh3)2}­(bpy)] n (X = Br and Cl) at room temperature have been previously reported, the structures were further determined at −120 °C for comparison purposes. The final cell parameters were obtained from a least-squares analysis of the reflections with I > 10σ­(I). Space group determination was performed on the basis of systematic absences, a statistical analysis of the intensity distribution, and the successful solution and refinement of the structures. Data were collected and processed using CrystalClear. An empirical absorption correction resulted in acceptable transmission factors. The data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization factors.

elements.content: All the calculations were carried out using CrystalStructure and SHELX-97. The ORTEP diagrams of the structures were prepared using ORTEP-III. The structures were solved by the direct method and expanded using Fourier and difference Fourier techniques. In the mixed-halogenido compounds, the halogen atoms were set at the same position with the same displacement factors, and the ratios of the occupation factors were refined. Details of the crystal parameters and structure refinement are given in Tables S4–S6. Selected atomic distances are shown in –.

Emission spectra were recorded on a photodiode array detector (Hamamatsu, C7473) and a N2 laser at 337 nm excitation. Excitation spectra were recorded on a JASCO Spectrofluorophotometer FP-8500. Emission lifetimes were determined on a Hamamatsu Photonics C4334 equipped with a streak camera as a photodetector at 337 nm. Single crystals were used for lifetime measurements at room temperature, whereas crushed samples between two quartz plates were used for measurement with a cryostat to hold the sample at an appropriate position in the cryostat. Photoluminescence quantum yields at 337 nm excitation and the absorption spectra were measured at room temperature in the solid state with an integrating sphere (Hamamatsu, C9920–03).
elements.clean_text:
Photophysical Measurements

Emission spectra were recorded on a photodiode array detector (Hamamatsu, C7473) and a N2 laser at 337 nm excitation. Excitation spectra were recorded on a JASCO Spectrofluorophotometer FP-8500. Emission lifetimes were determined on a Hamamatsu Photonics C4334 equipped with a streak camera as a photodetector at 337 nm. Single crystals were used for lifetime measurements at room temperature, whereas crushed samples between two quartz plates were used for measurement with a cryostat to hold the sample at an appropriate position in the cryostat. Photoluminescence quantum yields at 337 nm excitation and the absorption spectra were measured at room temperature in the solid state with an integrating sphere (Hamamatsu, C9920-03).

elements.content: The electronic structures were calculated using density functional theory (DFT) and time-dependent DFT (TD-DFT) with the Gaussian 09 program package in the hybrid Becke three-parameter Lee–Yang–Parr (B3LYP) functional level. The LanL2dz basis set was used for all atoms. The geometry of the model complexes were taken from the X-ray crystallographic data. The calculations of the model complexes in the solvent were performed using the polarizable continuum model. The components of molecular orbitals were calculated by Mulliken population analysis. Surface diagrams of MO were depicted by GaussView. The schematic diagrams of model complexes are shown in Scheme S1.
elements.clean_text:
Molecular-Orbital Calculations

The electronic structures were calculated using density functional theory (DFT) and time-dependent DFT (TD-DFT) with the Gaussian 09 program package in the hybrid Becke three-parameter Lee-Yang-Parr (B3LYP) functional level. The LanL2dz basis set was used for all atoms. The geometry of the model complexes were taken from the X-ray crystallographic data. The calculations of the model complexes in the solvent were performed using the polarizable continuum model. The components of molecular orbitals were calculated by Mulliken population analysis. Surface diagrams of MO were depicted by GaussView. The schematic diagrams of model complexes are shown in Scheme S1.

elements.content: A series of silver­(I) halogenido complexes with bridging bpy [Ag2X2(PPh3)2(μ-bpy)] n (X = I, Br, Cl) were prepared by reaction of AgX, PPh3, and bpy in organic solvent mixtures. The crystal structures of the iodido and chlorido complexes are shown in . Although their crystal structures have been previously reported, their structural differences and similarities are briefly discussed here in terms of the relationship between the structure and luminescence properties.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Structures of Homohalogenido Complexes

A series of silver(I) halogenido complexes with bridging bpy [Ag2X2(PPh3)2(μ-bpy)] n  (X = I, Br, Cl) were prepared by reaction of AgX, PPh3, and bpy in organic solvent mixtures. The crystal structures of the iodido and chlorido complexes are shown in . Although their crystal structures have been previously reported, their structural differences and similarities are briefly discussed here in terms of the relationship between the structure and luminescence properties.

elements.content: ORTEP drawing of (a) [Ag2I2(PPh3)2(μ-bpy)] n and (b) [Ag2Cl2(PPh3)2(μ-bpy)] n (probability: 50%). Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  ORTEP drawing of (a) [Ag2I2(PPh3)2(μ-bpy)] n  and (b) [Ag2Cl2(PPh3)2(μ-bpy)] n  (probability: 50%). Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: As shown in a, the two silver atoms are bridged by two iodido ligands forming a rhombic {Ag2(μ-I)2} unit, which is located in a crystallographic inversion center. Each of the silver atoms of the {Ag2I2} unit is further coordinated by PPh3 to form a {Ag2I2(PPh3)2} unit, which is connected by bpy, resulting in a one-dimensional chain structure that is common also to the bromido and chlorido complexes. As revealed by their lattice constants, the crystals of the iodido and bromido complexes are isomorphous, but those of the chlorido complex are not (Tables S4–S6). In the case of the iodido and bromido complexes, one silver atom, one halogenido ligand, one PPh3, and half a bpy ligand are crystallographically independent, rendering all {Ag2X2(PPh3)2} units equivalent in the crystal. This structure is common to the copper congeners [Cu2X2(PPh3)2(bpy)] n . On the other hand, twice of the atoms are crystallographically independent in the crystal of the chlorido complex, which includes two structurally inequivalent {Ag2Cl2(PPh3)2} units. The orientation of the phenyl groups changes alternately in the chlorido complex, as shown in b. While bpy adopts a planar structure in the iodido and bromido complexes because of the inversion center crystallographically imposed on it, the bridging bpy molecule in the chlorido complex deviates from planarity with a dihedral angle of 21.60(10)° between the two pyridine rings. The structural differences must thus be related to the size of the halogenido ligands (vide infra).

As revealed by their lattice constants, the crystals of the iodido and bromido complexes are isomorphous, but those of the chlorido complex are not (Tables S4-S6). In the case of the iodido and bromido complexes, one silver atom, one halogenido ligand, one PPh3, and half a bpy ligand are crystallographically independent, rendering all {Ag2X2(PPh3)2} units equivalent in the crystal. This structure is common to the copper congeners [Cu2X2(PPh3)2(bpy)] n . On the other hand, twice of the atoms are crystallographically independent in the crystal of the chlorido complex, which includes two structurally inequivalent {Ag2Cl2(PPh3)2} units. The orientation of the phenyl groups changes alternately in the chlorido complex, as shown in b. elements.content: Taking advantage of the isomorphous relation or structural similarities between the iodido, bromido, and chlorido complexes, we prepared mixed-halogenido complexes by a similar procedure to that employed for the homohalogenido parent complexes. The addition of bpy to a solution containing AgX, AgX′, and PPh3 yielded mixed-halogenido complexes [Ag2(X x X′(1–x))2(PPh3)2(bpy)] ((X, X′) = (I, Br), (I, Cl), (Br, Cl)) as single crystals, even in the case of the nonisomorphous combinations of iodido–chlorido and bromido–chlorido complexes. The molar fractions of halogenido ligands were determined from the CHN elemental analysis results, in good agreement with the values obtained from the single-crystal X-ray analysis (difference ≤ 0.1). Moreover, the determined molar fractions almost matched the reaction ratios (Tables S1–S3). In the case of the I–Br mixed-halogenido complexes, the fraction of halogenido ligands is almost consistent with the reaction ratio, whereas in the case of the Br–Cl and I–Cl mixed complexes, the chlorido fraction tended to be smaller than the reaction ratio. Hereafter, each sample is formulated on the basis of the elemental analysis results.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis and Structures of Mixed-Halogenido Complexes

Taking advantage of the isomorphous relation or structural similarities between the iodido, bromido, and chlorido complexes, we prepared mixed-halogenido complexes by a similar procedure to that employed for the homohalogenido parent complexes. The addition of bpy to a solution containing AgX, AgX', and PPh3 yielded mixed-halogenido complexes [Ag2(X x X'(1-x))2(PPh3)2(bpy)] ((X, X') = (I, Br), (I, Cl), (Br, Cl)) as single crystals, even in the case of the nonisomorphous combinations of iodido-chlorido and bromido-chlorido complexes. The molar fractions of halogenido ligands were determined from the CHN elemental analysis results, in good agreement with the values obtained from the single-crystal X-ray analysis (difference ≤ 0.1). Moreover, the determined molar fractions almost matched the reaction ratios (Tables S1-S3). In the case of the I-Br mixed-halogenido complexes, the fraction of halogenido ligands is almost consistent with the reaction ratio, whereas in the case of the Br-Cl and I-Cl mixed complexes, the chlorido fraction tended to be smaller than the reaction ratio. Hereafter, each sample is formulated on the basis of the elemental analysis results.

elements.content: The X-ray analysis revealed that the iodido–bromido mixed-halogenido complexes are isomorphous to the parent iodido and bromido complexes (Table S4). In the case of the bromido–chlorido mixed-halogenido complexes, the complexes form isomorphous crystals to those of either the bromido or chlorido complex (Table S5). The crystal structure analysis of the bromido–chlorido mixed-halogenido complexes indicates that the minor {Ag2X′2(PPh3)2(μ-bpy)} and {Ag2XX′(PPh3)2(μ-bpy)} units adopt the same structure as the major {Ag2X2(PPh3)2(μ-bpy)} unit, including the orientation of bpy. For example, at a chlorido molar fraction of 0.6, the crystal adopts a structure isomorphous to that of the chlorido complex (Table S5), which means that the {Ag2Br2(PPh3)2(μ-bpy)} units in the crystal adopt a structure identical to that of {Ag2Cl2(PPh3)2(μ-bpy)} in the chlorido complex. Thus, the bridging bpy in such crystals presents a distorted structure even when linking {Ag2Br2(PPh3)2} units. Such a situation is more prominent in the case of the iodido–chlorido mixed complexes. These iodido–chlorido complexes adopt a structure isomorphous to that of the iodido complex even at an iodido molar fraction of 0.3 (Table S6), which means that the {Ag2X2(PPh3)2(μ-bpy)} units adopt a structure with a planar bpy even when 70% of the halogenido ligands are chlorido, which prefers to form {Ag2X2(PPh3)2(μ-bpy)} units with distorted bpy ligands.
elements.clean_text: The X-ray analysis revealed that the iodido-bromido mixed-halogenido complexes are isomorphous to the parent iodido and bromido complexes (Table S4). In the case of the bromido-chlorido mixed-halogenido complexes, the complexes form isomorphous crystals to those of either the bromido or chlorido complex (Table S5). The crystal structure analysis of the bromido-chlorido mixed-halogenido complexes indicates that the minor {Ag2X'2(PPh3)2(μ-bpy)} and {Ag2XX'(PPh3)2(μ-bpy)} units adopt the same structure as the major {Ag2X2(PPh3)2(μ-bpy)} unit, including the orientation of bpy. For example, at a chlorido molar fraction of 0.6, the crystal adopts a structure isomorphous to that of the chlorido complex (Table S5), which means that the {Ag2Br2(PPh3)2(μ-bpy)} units in the crystal adopt a structure identical to that of {Ag2Cl2(PPh3)2(μ-bpy)} in the chlorido complex. Thus, the bridging bpy in such crystals presents a distorted structure even when linking {Ag2Br2(PPh3)2} units. Such a situation is more prominent in the case of the iodido-chlorido mixed complexes. These iodido-chlorido complexes adopt a structure isomorphous to that of the iodido complex even at an iodido molar fraction of 0.3 (Table S6), which means that the {Ag2X2(PPh3)2(μ-bpy)} units adopt a structure with a planar bpy even when 70% of the halogenido ligands are chlorido, which prefers to form {Ag2X2(PPh3)2(μ-bpy)} units with distorted bpy ligands.

elements.content: shows the average Ag–X distances found in each crystal. In the case of the I–Br mixed complexes, the Ag–X distance changes almost linearly with the Br fraction. On the other hand, in the case of the I–Cl and Br–Cl mixed complexes, the Ag–X distance changes nonlinearly at the fraction where the structure type changes. From , it can be deduced that the mixed-halogenido complexes tend to form isomorphous crystals to those of the chlorido complex when the weighted average of Ag–X distances is smaller than ∼2.7 Å. Because each coordination polymer chain {Ag2X2(PPh3)2(μ-bpy)} n can be regarded as a {Ag2X2(μ-bpy)} n chain surrounded by bulky PPh3 ligands, the intra- and interchain repulsion between PPh3 moieties strongly affects the arrangement of the polymer chains and the overall crystal structure. Because the size of the {Ag2Cl2} unit is smaller than that of {Ag2Br2} and {Ag2I2}, the {Ag2Cl2(μ-bpy)} chain shrinks compared to those of the bromido and iodido complexes, inducing greater repulsion between the PPh3 ligands. To reduce such increased repulsion, PPh3 probably adopts a different orientation in the chlorido complexes, resulting in a slight distortion of the bpy bridge by the different steric effects of PPh3. implies that the d Ag–X(av) of 2.7 Å corresponds to the threshold size of the {Ag2X2} units between the two structures.

elements.content:
As shown in , the iodido and bromido complexes show a similar-energy band at ∼450 nm with lifetimes of 22 and 307 μs, respectively.

The related copper­(I) complexes [Cu2X2(PPh3)2(bpy)] have been reported to display a broad band at ∼530 nm. The bands of the copper­(I) complexes have been assigned to charge-transfer (CT) transitions from the {Cu2X2} core to the bpy ligand. The coincidence of emission bands for the iodido and bromido silver­(I) complexes and clear progression observed at lower temperatures indicate that the emission bands are assignable to ligand-centered transitions ().
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Properties of Homohalogenido Complexes

As shown in , the iodido and bromido complexes show a similar-energy band at ~450 nm with lifetimes of 22 and 307 μs, respectively.

The related copper(I) complexes [Cu2X2(PPh3)2(bpy)] have been reported to display a broad band at ~530 nm. The bands of the copper(I) complexes have been assigned to charge-transfer (CT) transitions from the {Cu2X2} core to the bpy ligand. The coincidence of emission bands for the iodido and bromido silver(I) complexes and clear progression observed at lower temperatures indicate that the emission bands are assignable to ligand-centered transitions ().

elements.content: Emission spectra of [Ag2X2(PPh3)2(bpy)] at room temperature (λex: 337 nm). (Black: X = I, red: X = Br, blue: X = Cl).
elements.clean_text: 3  Emission spectra of [Ag2X2(PPh3)2(bpy)] at room temperature (λex: 337 nm). (Black: X = I, red: X = Br, blue: X = Cl).

elements.clean_text: 4  Emission spectra of [Ag2X2(PPh3)2(bpy)] at various temperatures: (a) X = I, (b) X = Br, (c) X = Cl. Blue: 80 K, sky blue: 110 K, green: 170 K, orange: 230 K, and red: 290 K; λex: 337 nm.

elements.content: From their spectra at 80 K, the energies of the coupling vibrational bands are estimated as 1.6 × 103 and 1.3 × 103 cm–1, which correspond to the vibrational bands of bpy ligands (Figure S1). Therefore, the emission bands of both iodido and bromido complexes are assigned to phosphorescence from π–π*-transitions in the bpy ligand. The longer lifetimes also support such ligand-based phosphorescence (vide infra).
elements.clean_text: From their spectra at 80 K, the energies of the coupling vibrational bands are estimated as 1.6 × 103 and 1.3 × 103 cm-1, which correspond to the vibrational bands of bpy ligands (Figure S1). Therefore, the emission bands of both iodido and bromido complexes are assigned to phosphorescence from π-π*-transitions in the bpy ligand. The longer lifetimes also support such ligand-based phosphorescence (vide infra).

elements.content: On the other hand, the chlorido complex shows a broad emission band at λmax = 520 nm with a lifetime of 110 μs at room temperature, implying that the origin of its emission is different from that of the bromido and iodido complexes. At lower temperatures, however, the chlorido complex displays a higher energy band with the progression in addition to the initial broad band (c). The intensities of the lower and higher energy bands decrease and increase with the decreasing temperature, respectively, and at 80 K, the chlorido complex shows only the higher energy band, as in the case of the iodido and bromido complexes. Figure S3 shows the emission decay at various temperatures. Although lifetime elongation is commonly observed for complexes at low temperatures, the changes in the chlorido complex are remarkable. The emission lifetime of the chlorido complex reaches 2 ms at 80 K (). This long emission lifetime, together with the coincidence of the energy and band shape, clearly demonstrates that the emission of the chlorido complex at low temperatures is assignable to the π–π*-transition in the bpy ligand, as in the case of the iodido and bromido complexes.
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, the chlorido complex shows a broad emission band at λmax = 520 nm with a lifetime of 110 μs at room temperature, implying that the origin of its emission is different from that of the bromido and iodido complexes. At lower temperatures, however, the chlorido complex displays a higher energy band with the progression in addition to the initial broad band (c). The intensities of the lower and higher energy bands decrease and increase with the decreasing temperature, respectively, and at 80 K, the chlorido complex shows only the higher energy band, as in the case of the iodido and bromido complexes. Figure S3 shows the emission decay at various temperatures. Although lifetime elongation is commonly observed for complexes at low temperatures, the changes in the chlorido complex are remarkable. The emission lifetime of the chlorido complex reaches 2 ms at 80 K (). This long emission lifetime, together with the coincidence of the energy and band shape, clearly demonstrates that the emission of the chlorido complex at low temperatures is assignable to the π-π*-transition in the bpy ligand, as in the case of the iodido and bromido complexes.

The lower energy band of the chlorido complex can be assigned to the CT transition from the {M2X2} core to the bpy ligand because of its broad band shape and shorter lifetime, as also supported by molecular-orbital calculations (vide infra). Such characteristic behavior of the chlorido complex is reminiscent of that of copper­(I) complexes with a {Cu4I4} core, whereas the competing emissive excited states correspond to MLCT and cluster-centered CT states in those complexes. Because the chlorido complex presents a different crystal structure than the other two complexes, its characteristic emission reflects the structural and/or electronic differences between the halogenido ligands, as reflected in the luminescence properties of mixed-halogenido complexes.

elements.content: The absorption and excitation spectra of the iodido, bromido, and chlorido complexes are shown in Figure S4. The band edges appear at around 400 nm showing a blue shift in the order of iodido, bromido, and chlorido of ∼15 nm (0.1 eV). Although a clear definition of absorption band energy is not easy from the solid-state spectra, hereafter, the band edge values in the excitation spectra (400, 385, and 370 nm for iodido, bromido, and chlorido, respectively) are used to discuss the band energy.
elements.clean_text:
Absorption and Excitation Spectra of Homohalogenido Complexes

The absorption and excitation spectra of the iodido, bromido, and chlorido complexes are shown in Figure S4. The band edges appear at around 400 nm showing a blue shift in the order of iodido, bromido, and chlorido of ~15 nm (0.1 eV). Although a clear definition of absorption band energy is not easy from the solid-state spectra, hereafter, the band edge values in the excitation spectra (400, 385, and 370 nm for iodido, bromido, and chlorido, respectively) are used to discuss the band energy.

elements.content: After consideration of the band shifts and the results of calculations (vide infra), the lowest absorption bands can be ascribed to CT from the {Ag2X2} core to the bpy π*-orbital, although the complexes display emission bands assignable to 3π–π*-transitions in bpy, as described above. These observations indicate that the 1π–π* excited state is located higher in energy than the 1CT excited state, but the 3π–π*-excited-state is located slightly lower than the 3CT excited state in these complexes.
elements.clean_text: After consideration of the band shifts and the results of calculations (vide infra), the lowest absorption bands can be ascribed to CT from the {Ag2X2} core to the bpy π*-orbital, although the complexes display emission bands assignable to 3π-π*-transitions in bpy, as described above. These observations indicate that the 1π-π* excited state is located higher in energy than the 1CT excited state, but the 3π-π*-excited-state is located slightly lower than the 3CT excited state in these complexes.

elements.content: The luminescence spectra of the iodido–bromido mixed-halogenido complexes are shown in , together with their emission decays. As expected from the properties of the parent homohalogenido complexes, the emission bands are almost identical to those of the parent complexes. Each emission decay curve (b) was fitted with a single-exponential function. Their apparent lifetimes and quantum yields are shown in . Because the emission lifetimes of the iodido (22 μs) and bromido (307 μs) complexes are largely different, the emission decays should not be single-exponential but at least biexponential if each site emits independently.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Properties of Mixed-Halogenido Complexes

The luminescence spectra of the iodido-bromido mixed-halogenido complexes are shown in , together with their emission decays. As expected from the properties of the parent homohalogenido complexes, the emission bands are almost identical to those of the parent complexes. Each emission decay curve (b) was fitted with a single-exponential function. Their apparent lifetimes and quantum yields are shown in . Because the emission lifetimes of the iodido (22 μs) and bromido (307 μs) complexes are largely different, the emission decays should not be single-exponential but at least biexponential if each site emits independently.

The single-exponential decay demonstrates that energy migration occurs smoothly between the iodido and bromido sites or faster than the intrinsic lifetimes of each excited state in the iodido–bromido mixed-halogenido complexes. The gradual changes in the lifetime and quantum yield with the molar fraction indicate that the character of the emissive excited states of the iodido and bromido sites remains substantially intact in the iodido–bromido mixed-halogenido complexes.

elements.content: a shows the emission spectra of the bromido–chlorido mixed-halogenido complexes. At chlorido ligand fractions smaller than 0.4, the emission spectra are identical to those of the bromido complex, whereas they are almost identical to those of the chlorido complex at chlorido contents above 0.6. As shown in b, the complexes display single-exponential emission decay curves like those of the iodido–bromido mixed complexes, clearly demonstrating the rapid energy migration between the luminophores in the bromido–chlorido complexes. Their emission lifetimes () reflect the abrupt changes corresponding to the spectral changes. At chlorido molar fractions smaller than 0.4, the lifetimes of the complexes are as long as that of the parent bromido complex (ca. 300 μs), whereas they are as short as that of the chlorido complex (ca. 100 μs) at chlorido molar fractions above 0.6.

The luminescence spectra of the I–Cl complexes are shown in a. Most of them show lifetimes almost identical to that of the iodido complex at chlorido fractions below 0.6 and similar to that of the chlorido complex when the chlorido content reaches 0.9. Their emission lifetimes are single-exponential, as those of the other mixed-halogenido complexes, implying smooth energy migration. The lifetimes are as short (<30 μs) as that of the parent iodido complex at chlorido molar fractions below 0.35 but increase to 63 and 52 μs at molar fractions of 0.6 and 0.9, respectively ().

As mentioned above, the emission spectra and lifetimes demonstrate that the lowest emissive excited state is the 3π–π*-state of bpy in all homohalogenido complexes, whereas the absorption and excitation spectra indicate that the lowest singlet excited state is assignable to CT from the {Ag2X2} core to the bpy π*-orbital. In addition, the luminescence thermochromic behavior of the chlorido complex implies that the 3CT excited state is located closely above the 3π–π*-state in energy.
elements.clean_text:
Electronic Structures of Homohalogenido Complexes

As mentioned above, the emission spectra and lifetimes demonstrate that the lowest emissive excited state is the 3π-π*-state of bpy in all homohalogenido complexes, whereas the absorption and excitation spectra indicate that the lowest singlet excited state is assignable to CT from the {Ag2X2} core to the bpy π*-orbital. In addition, the luminescence thermochromic behavior of the chlorido complex implies that the 3CT excited state is located closely above the 3π-π*-state in energy.

elements.content: To discuss the electronic structure of [Ag2X2(PPh3)2(μ-bpy)] n , we performed DFT and TD-DFT calculations on several discrete model complexes with geometric parameters taken from the structures determined by single-crystal X-ray analysis (Scheme S1). Focusing on the {Ag2I2(PPh3)2} core, we calculated the discrete model complex [Ag2I2(PPh3)2(bpy)2] (1–I) (Scheme S1b). In 1–I, the highest occupied molecular-orbital (HOMO) and occupied molecular orbitals (OMOs) energetically close to the HOMO are mainly composed of the iodine 5p-orbitals mixed with the silver 4d-orbitals in a silver–iodine antibonding manner, thus being localized on the {Ag2I2} core (Table S7). The lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) is mostly the pure bpy π*-orbital, above which are located the π*-orbitals of the phenyl groups of PPh3. The electronic structure of 1–I is reminiscent of that of the copper congeners, where the HOMO and OMOs close to the HOMO are mainly composed of the copper 3d and halogen np-orbitals, and the LUMO is the π*-orbital of the N-heteroaromatic ligand. Because the silver 4d-orbitals are more stable than the copper 3d-orbitals, the HOMO is more stable and contains a larger component of halogen np-orbitals in the silver complexes than in the copper complexes, resulting in a larger HOMO–LUMO gap and more X–L CT character in the HOMO–LUMO transitions in the silver complexes.
elements.clean_text: To discuss the electronic structure of [Ag2X2(PPh3)2(μ-bpy)] n , we performed DFT and TD-DFT calculations on several discrete model complexes with geometric parameters taken from the structures determined by single-crystal X-ray analysis (Scheme S1). Focusing on the {Ag2I2(PPh3)2} core, we calculated the discrete model complex [Ag2I2(PPh3)2(bpy)2] (1-I) (Scheme S1b). In 1-I, the highest occupied molecular-orbital (HOMO) and occupied molecular orbitals (OMOs) energetically close to the HOMO are mainly composed of the iodine 5p-orbitals mixed with the silver 4d-orbitals in a silver-iodine antibonding manner, thus being localized on the {Ag2I2} core (Table S7). The lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) is mostly the pure bpy π*-orbital, above which are located the π*-orbitals of the phenyl groups of PPh3. The electronic structure of 1-I is reminiscent of that of the copper congeners, where the HOMO and OMOs close to the HOMO are mainly composed of the copper 3d and halogen np-orbitals, and the LUMO is the π*-orbital of the N-heteroaromatic ligand. Because the silver 4d-orbitals are more stable than the copper 3d-orbitals, the HOMO is more stable and contains a larger component of halogen np-orbitals in the silver complexes than in the copper complexes, resulting in a larger HOMO-LUMO gap and more X-L CT character in the HOMO-LUMO transitions in the silver complexes.

elements.content: Because emission from the 3π–π*-state of bpy was observed, calculations focusing on the electronic structures of the bridging bpy were also carried out using a tetranuclear model complex [py–{Ag2I2(PPh3)2}–bpy–{Ag2I2(PPh3)2}–py] (2–I), where the surroundings of bpy are more precisely reproduced (Scheme S1c). The molecular orbitals and energies of 2–I are similar to those of 1–I, indicating the rather localized nature of MOs at each site (Table S8). As for the occupied orbitals, the HOMO and OMOs energetically close to HOMO (HOMO–H-11) are composed of the iodine 5p-orbitals mixed with silver 4d-orbitals, followed by the four Ag–P and Ag–N σ-antibonding orbitals (H-12–H-15), 24 π-orbitals of the phenyl rings (H-16–H-39), and finally the bpy π-orbital mixed with the Ag 4d-orbital in a π-antibonding manner (H-40). Similar to that in 1–I, the LUMO corresponds to the pure bpy π*-orbital, followed by the vacant π*-orbitals of py and PPh3 (Table S8). The calculations for both models yielded similar-energy patterns, where the HOMO is mostly localized on the {Ag2I2} core, and the LUMO is the π*-orbital of bpy, corresponding to the CT character of the lowest absorption band.
elements.clean_text: Because emission from the 3π-π*-state of bpy was observed, calculations focusing on the electronic structures of the bridging bpy were also carried out using a tetranuclear model complex [py-{Ag2I2(PPh3)2}-bpy-{Ag2I2(PPh3)2}-py] (2-I), where the surroundings of bpy are more precisely reproduced (Scheme S1c). The molecular orbitals and energies of 2-I are similar to those of 1-I, indicating the rather localized nature of MOs at each site (Table S8). As for the occupied orbitals, the HOMO and OMOs energetically close to HOMO (HOMO-H-11) are composed of the iodine 5p-orbitals mixed with silver 4d-orbitals, followed by the four Ag-P and Ag-N σ-antibonding orbitals (H-12-H-15), 24 π-orbitals of the phenyl rings (H-16-H-39), and finally the bpy π-orbital mixed with the Ag 4d-orbital in a π-antibonding manner (H-40). Similar to that in 1-I, the LUMO corresponds to the pure bpy π*-orbital, followed by the vacant π*-orbitals of py and PPh3 (Table S8). The calculations for both models yielded similar-energy patterns, where the HOMO is mostly localized on the {Ag2I2} core, and the LUMO is the π*-orbital of bpy, corresponding to the CT character of the lowest absorption band.

elements.content: The calculations on the bromido and chlorido model complexes [py–{Ag2X2(PPh3)2}–bpy–Ag2X2(PPh3)2}–py] (2–X) (X = Br, Cl) afforded similar results with substantially the same orbitals and energies (Tables S9 and S10).
elements.clean_text: The calculations on the bromido and chlorido model complexes [py-{Ag2X2(PPh3)2}-bpy-Ag2X2(PPh3)2}-py] (2-X) (X = Br, Cl) afforded similar results with substantially the same orbitals and energies (Tables S9 and S10).

elements.content: To discuss the excited states of the complexes, we carried out TD-DFT calculations. Because 2–X, bearing four PPh3, two pyridine, and one bpy, is too large for TD-DFT calculations in our calculation system, we used the tetranuclear models [{(NH3)­(PH3)­(Ag2X2)­(PPh3)}–bpy–{(PPh3)­(Ag2X2)­(NH3)­(PH3)}] (X = I, Br, Cl) (3–X), where the terminal silver ions are coordinated by PH3 and NH3 instead of PPh3 and py, respectively (Tables S11–S16). The orbitals and their energies around the frontier orbitals of 3–I are almost the same as those of 2–I except for the absence of the π-orbitals of the phenyl and pyridine rings (Tables S8 and S11 and Figure S5): The LUMO is the vacant bpy π*-orbital, and the HOMO consists of the iodine 5p-orbitals mixed with silver 4d-orbitals, followed by the iodine 5p-orbitals mixed with silver 4d-orbitals (H-1–H-11), Ag–P and Ag–N σ-antibonding orbitals (H-12–H-15), 12 π-orbitals of the phenyl rings of PPh3 (H-16–H-27), and then the bpy π-orbital mixed with the silver 4d-orbital in a π-antibonding manner (H-28). As shown in Figure S5, the correspondence of these orbitals for 2–I and 3–I supports the validity of the TD-DFT calculations using 3–I in terms of lower energy transitions. The bromido and chlorido model complexes 3–Br and 3–Cl also show almost the same values as 2–Br and 2–Cl, respectively (Tables S13 and S15 and Figure S5).
elements.clean_text: To discuss the excited states of the complexes, we carried out TD-DFT calculations. Because 2-X, bearing four PPh3, two pyridine, and one bpy, is too large for TD-DFT calculations in our calculation system, we used the tetranuclear models [{(NH3)(PH3)(Ag2X2)(PPh3)}-bpy-{(PPh3)(Ag2X2)(NH3)(PH3)}] (X = I, Br, Cl) (3-X), where the terminal silver ions are coordinated by PH3 and NH3 instead of PPh3 and py, respectively (Tables S11-S16). The orbitals and their energies around the frontier orbitals of 3-I are almost the same as those of 2-I except for the absence of the π-orbitals of the phenyl and pyridine rings (Tables S8 and S11 and Figure S5): The LUMO is the vacant bpy π*-orbital, and the HOMO consists of the iodine 5p-orbitals mixed with silver 4d-orbitals, followed by the iodine 5p-orbitals mixed with silver 4d-orbitals (H-1-H-11), Ag-P and Ag-N σ-antibonding orbitals (H-12-H-15), 12 π-orbitals of the phenyl rings of PPh3 (H-16-H-27), and then the bpy π-orbital mixed with the silver 4d-orbital in a π-antibonding manner (H-28). As shown in Figure S5, the correspondence of these orbitals for 2-I and 3-I supports the validity of the TD-DFT calculations using 3-I in terms of lower energy transitions. The bromido and chlorido model complexes 3-Br and 3-Cl also show almost the same values as 2-Br and 2-Cl, respectively (Tables S13 and S15 and Figure S5).

elements.content: As expected from their MO diagrams, the calculated S1 state of 3–X corresponds to a HOMO-to-LUMO transition (Tables S12, S14, and S16), namely, the {Ag2X2} core-to-bpy π*-orbital transition, whose energy was calculated as 2.22, 2.35, and 2.53 eV for the iodido, bromido, and chlorido complexes, respectively. Because the LUMO is the pure bpy π*-orbital in each model, the energy difference of S1 states across the 3–X (X = I, Br, Cl) species is mainly ascribed to the energy difference of the HOMOs, which is mainly influenced by the stability of the X np-orbitals. The energy difference of the calculated values is ∼0.15 eV, in agreement with the observed values and supporting the CT character of the observed bands. The absolute value of each S1 state, however, is lower than those observed by 0.8–0.9 eV. In addition, the calculated T1 states of 3–X are the HOMO–LUMO transitions as the S1 states, showing that the calculated lowest triplet state is the CT state, in conflict with the observations. Thus, the calculations do not fully explain the observations. Although we performed the calculations of the complexes in vacuum to avoid possible artifacts, underestimation of these CT-type excited states implies an overestimation of the HOMO or underestimation of the LUMO for 3–X in vacuum.
elements.clean_text: As expected from their MO diagrams, the calculated S1 state of 3-X corresponds to a HOMO-to-LUMO transition (Tables S12, S14, and S16), namely, the {Ag2X2} core-to-bpy π*-orbital transition, whose energy was calculated as 2.22, 2.35, and 2.53 eV for the iodido, bromido, and chlorido complexes, respectively. Because the LUMO is the pure bpy π*-orbital in each model, the energy difference of S1 states across the 3-X (X = I, Br, Cl) species is mainly ascribed to the energy difference of the HOMOs, which is mainly influenced by the stability of the X np-orbitals. The energy difference of the calculated values is ~0.15 eV, in agreement with the observed values and supporting the CT character of the observed bands. The absolute value of each S1 state, however, is lower than those observed by 0.8-0.9 eV. In addition, the calculated T1 states of 3-X are the HOMO-LUMO transitions as the S1 states, showing that the calculated lowest triplet state is the CT state, in conflict with the observations. Thus, the calculations do not fully explain the observations. Although we performed the calculations of the complexes in vacuum to avoid possible artifacts, underestimation of these CT-type excited states implies an overestimation of the HOMO or underestimation of the LUMO for 3-X in vacuum.

elements.content: Next, we performed calculations on 3–X in a dielectric medium to effectively reproduce the emissive sites in the crystals, where the polymeric chain is surrounded by other chains containing charged ions and π-electrons, possibly showing electronic polarizability. The calculations on 3–I in DMSO showed a stabilization of the HOMO and LUMO by 0.61 and 0.04 eV, respectively, compared to those in vacuum (Tables S11 and S17). The energy of the S1 state was calculated as 2.79 eV, destabilized by 0.57 eV and reflecting the stabilization of the HOMO. The difference with the observed value (3.08 eV) also becomes as small as 0.3 eV (Table S18). In the case of the bromido and chlorido complexes, the stabilization of the HOMO and LUMO energies is 0.67 and 0.10 eV and 0.80 and 0.21 eV, respectively (Tables S13, S15, S19, and S21). Reflecting these changes, the calculated energy of each S1 state becomes 2.92 and 3.12 eV for the bromido and chlorido complexes, respectively (Tables S20 and S22). The energy difference between the observed and calculated values becomes smaller for the bromido and chlorido complexes, as in the calculations of the iodido complex. These improvements indicate that the HOMO energy is likely overestimated for the models in vacuum, probably because of overestimation of the energies of protruding lone pairs in vacuum, which should be sensitive to the surroundings.
elements.clean_text: Next, we performed calculations on 3-X in a dielectric medium to effectively reproduce the emissive sites in the crystals, where the polymeric chain is surrounded by other chains containing charged ions and π-electrons, possibly showing electronic polarizability. The calculations on 3-I in DMSO showed a stabilization of the HOMO and LUMO by 0.61 and 0.04 eV, respectively, compared to those in vacuum (Tables S11 and S17). The energy of the S1 state was calculated as 2.79 eV, destabilized by 0.57 eV and reflecting the stabilization of the HOMO. The difference with the observed value (3.08 eV) also becomes as small as 0.3 eV (Table S18). In the case of the bromido and chlorido complexes, the stabilization of the HOMO and LUMO energies is 0.67 and 0.10 eV and 0.80 and 0.21 eV, respectively (Tables S13, S15, S19, and S21). Reflecting these changes, the calculated energy of each S1 state becomes 2.92 and 3.12 eV for the bromido and chlorido complexes, respectively (Tables S20 and S22). The energy difference between the observed and calculated values becomes smaller for the bromido and chlorido complexes, as in the calculations of the iodido complex. These improvements indicate that the HOMO energy is likely overestimated for the models in vacuum, probably because of overestimation of the energies of protruding lone pairs in vacuum, which should be sensitive to the surroundings.

elements.content: Although the energy difference between the calculated and observed S1 states is largely reduced by stabilization of the HOMO in the calculations in DMSO, the T1 states are still calculated as HOMO–LUMO transitions, namely, the core-to-bpy CT state, as in the calculations in vacuum. However, the energy difference between the 3CT and 3π–π*-transitions is smaller in 3–X in DMSO than in vacuum. Tables S23 and S24 list the energies and components of the MOs mainly composed of bpy π*- and π-orbitals, together with the HOMO. Because the π-orbitals of bpy have a similar energy to the Ag 5d-orbitals and/or Ph π-orbitals in 3–X in vacuum, mixing occurs between them, making a simple comparison difficult (Table S23). However, in contrast to the ∼0.6 eV change of the HOMO–LUMO­(π*) gap (−0.57, −0.58, −0.59 eV, respectively, for X = I, Br, Cl), that of the π–LUMO­(π*) gap is less than 0.1 eV. Thus, the energy difference of the 3CT and 3π–π* -states becomes smaller for the calculations in DMSO than those in vacuum. By reduction of the energy difference between the 3CT and 3π–π*-transitions, mixing of the transitions corresponding to the π–π*-state into CT states is found in the lower energy triplet transitions in 3–X in DMSO. In 3–Cl in DMSO, even a small component of a π–π*-transition of bpy (H-27 → LUMO) is introduced in T1 (Table S22), which was not observed for transitions energetically higher than T9 in the calculations in vacuum (Tables S12, S14, and S16).

elements.content: The calculations on 3–X in DMSO revealed that the HOMO and following OMOs mainly composed of halogen np-orbitals are more sensitive to the surroundings than the π-orbitals of bpy, causing a reduction of the energy difference between the 3CT and 3π–π*-states. Therefore, if the HOMO level is calculated to be slightly more stable, the calculations reproduce the observations more precisely, namely, the 1CT state as S1 and the 3π–π*-state as T1. Comparison of the observed and calculated values for 3–X in DMSO indicates that the energies of the HOMO and following OMOs mainly composed of halogen np-orbitals are still overestimated by about 0.3 eV.

elements.content: The mixing of the π–π*-components to T1 in the chlorido model complex 3–Cl should also be noted, because it shows the smallest energy difference between 3CT and 3π–π* compared to the bromido and iodido complexes, thus explaining the thermochromic behavior of the chlorido complex arising from emissive excited states close in energy.
elements.clean_text: The mixing of the π-π*-components to T1 in the chlorido model complex 3-Cl should also be noted, because it shows the smallest energy difference between 3CT and 3π-π* compared to the bromido and iodido complexes, thus explaining the thermochromic behavior of the chlorido complex arising from emissive excited states close in energy.

elements.content: In the mixed-halogenido complexes, a clear correlation between the emission and crystal structure was observed. As mentioned above, among the Br–Cl mixed complexes, those isomorphous to the bromido complex do not show the CT-type emission characteristics of the chlorido sites but only the π–π*-emission characteristics of the bromido ones, whereas those isomorphous to the chlorido complex do not show π–π*-emission but only CT-type emission. Because a single-exponential emission decay demonstrates smooth, rapid energy migration across the emissive sites, the observed emissions of the Br–Cl mixed complexes should correspond to emissions from both the bromido and chlorido sites in each complex. Thus, the observation of either bromido- or chlorido-type emission for the Br–Cl mixed complexes implies a modification of the electronic structure of the chlorido and bromido sites in the crystals isomorphous to the bromido and chlorido complexes, respectively. The appearance of 3π–π*-emission without 3CT emission suggests that the 3π–π*-state becomes more stable than the 3CT state in the crystals isomorphous to the bromido ones, even though the {Ag2Cl2(bpy)} units are included. Indeed, the calculations for the chlorido model complex 4–Cl with a planar bpy showed that the 3CT and 3π–π*-states are stabilized by 0.071 and 0.086 eV, respectively (Tables S22 and S26). The larger stabilization of the 3π–π*-state than that of the 3CT state for 4–Cl agrees with the observed spectral changes.
elements.clean_text:
Relation between the Excited-State Energy and Structure in Mixed-Halogenido Complexes

In the mixed-halogenido complexes, a clear correlation between the emission and crystal structure was observed. As mentioned above, among the Br-Cl mixed complexes, those isomorphous to the bromido complex do not show the CT-type emission characteristics of the chlorido sites but only the π-π*-emission characteristics of the bromido ones, whereas those isomorphous to the chlorido complex do not show π-π*-emission but only CT-type emission. Because a single-exponential emission decay demonstrates smooth, rapid energy migration across the emissive sites, the observed emissions of the Br-Cl mixed complexes should correspond to emissions from both the bromido and chlorido sites in each complex. Thus, the observation of either bromido- or chlorido-type emission for the Br-Cl mixed complexes implies a modification of the electronic structure of the chlorido and bromido sites in the crystals isomorphous to the bromido and chlorido complexes, respectively. The appearance of 3π-π*-emission without 3CT emission suggests that the 3π-π*-state becomes more stable than the 3CT state in the crystals isomorphous to the bromido ones, even though the {Ag2Cl2(bpy)} units are included. Indeed, the calculations for the chlorido model complex 4-Cl with a planar bpy showed that the 3CT and 3π-π*-states are stabilized by 0.071 and 0.086 eV, respectively (Tables S22 and S26). The larger stabilization of the 3π-π*-state than that of the 3CT state for 4-Cl agrees with the observed spectral changes.

elements.content: To elucidate the changes in the excited states, we compared the orbitals and their energies for 4–Cl with those of 3–Cl. Because the structural changes are subtle, the electronic structure is almost the same in 4–Cl and 3–Cl. No substantial changes are observed in the energy and components of the HOMO, probably because of its localized nature on the {Ag2Cl2} core, and because the lone pair of bpy, which can affect the stability of the silver orbitals as a donating orbital, is not altered by planarization (Tables S21 and S25). On the other hand, the LUMO of 4–Cl is stabilized by 0.074 eV while retaining a pure bpy π*-character. The stabilization is explained from its bonding nature around the central C–C bond, which results in better positive overlap upon planarization of bpy (Figures S6 and S7). In contrast to the π*-orbital, the π-orbital displays antibonding nature around the central C–C bond, being destabilized upon planarization. H-27 (−7.55 eV) in 4–Cl contains the largest component of the highest π-orbital (54%) and is destabilized by 0.05 eV relative to H-28 (−7.60 eV, 59%) in 3–Cl. Because the π-orbital is mixed with silver d-orbitals, a simple comparison of orbitals between 3–Cl and 4–Cl is not straightforward, but the energies of the π-orbitals are considered to be destabilized to this extent (∼0.03 eV) in 4–Cl. Thus, while the calculated energies of T n for 4–Cl are not consistent with the observed energies, scrutiny of the electronic structure of 4–Cl supports that the stabilization of 3π–π* is induced by both the stabilization of the π*-orbital (∼0.07 eV) and destabilization of the π-orbital (∼0.03 eV), being larger than that of 3CT caused only by stabilization of the π*-orbital after planarization of the bpy structure. These energy changes are small but should be enough to modify the luminescence properties of the chlorido sites in the present systems, because the energy difference between 3CT and 3π–π* is actually small, as proved by their thermochromic behavior.

elements.content: The lack of a π–π*-band for the Br–Cl mixed complexes isomorphous to the chlorido complex can be explained in the same way. In the complexes, the bromido site is associated with the planar bpy, where opposite changes take place for the π- and π*-orbitals, rendering the 3CT state an accessible triplet excited state because of the large destabilization of the 3π–π*-state. The discussion is also applicable to the emissive properties of the I–Cl mixed complexes. The lack of a 3CT band, even at chlorido molar ratios of 0.6, is acceptable if the 3π–π*-state of the chlorido site is stabilized by the planar bpy.

elements.content: Thus, the bromido–chlorido complexes and the iodido–chlorido complexes show emission from the 3π–π*-state when they adopt a structure isomorphous to those of the bromido or iodido complexes with a planar bpy, even when the majority of halogenido ligands are chlorido ligands.

elements.content: Three silver­(I) halogenido coordination polymers with bridging bpy ligands, [Ag2X2(PPh3)2(μ-bpy)] n (X = I, Br, Cl), were found to be strongly emissive in the solid state at room temperature. The iodido and bromido complexes are isomorphous and exhibit a structured emission band assignable to 3π–π*-transitions at room temperature as well as at lower temperatures. The chlorido complex, with a slightly different structure with nonplanar bpy, displays dual emission with a low-energy broad band and a high-energy structured band assignable to 3CT and 3π–π*-transitions, respectively. The molecular-orbital calculations showed that the 3π–π*-excited-state and triplet {Ag2X2} core-to-L CT excited state are comparable in energy and that the 3π–π*-state is more destabilized than the 3CT state because of distortion of the bpy structure, which is likely the origin of the dual emission observed for the chlorido complex with nonplanar bpy ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Three silver(I) halogenido coordination polymers with bridging bpy ligands, [Ag2X2(PPh3)2(μ-bpy)] n  (X = I, Br, Cl), were found to be strongly emissive in the solid state at room temperature. The iodido and bromido complexes are isomorphous and exhibit a structured emission band assignable to 3π-π*-transitions at room temperature as well as at lower temperatures. The chlorido complex, with a slightly different structure with nonplanar bpy, displays dual emission with a low-energy broad band and a high-energy structured band assignable to 3CT and 3π-π*-transitions, respectively. The molecular-orbital calculations showed that the 3π-π*-excited-state and triplet {Ag2X2} core-to-L CT excited state are comparable in energy and that the 3π-π*-state is more destabilized than the 3CT state because of distortion of the bpy structure, which is likely the origin of the dual emission observed for the chlorido complex with nonplanar bpy ligands.

elements.content: A series of mixed-halogenido complexes [{Ag2(X(1–x)X′ x )2(PPh3)2}­(bpy)] n were prepared by similar methods to those for the parent homohalogenido complexes by reaction of a mixture of AgX and AgX′, PPh3, and bpy. The iodido–bromido complexes produce crystals that are isomorphous to those of the parent complexes, whose emission bands are the overlay of those of the parent complexes, and whose emission decays are single-exponential with lifetimes that are intermediate relative to those of the parent complexes. The results show that the photophysical properties of each emissive site remain substantially intact (i.e., those of the parent complexes) and that energy migration between the emissive sites is faster than the radiative and nonradiative rate constants of each state.

The iodido-bromido complexes produce crystals that are isomorphous to those of the parent complexes, whose emission bands are the overlay of those of the parent complexes, and whose emission decays are single-exponential with lifetimes that are intermediate relative to those of the parent complexes. The results show that the photophysical properties of each emissive site remain substantially intact (i.e., those of the parent complexes) and that energy migration between the emissive sites is faster than the radiative and nonradiative rate constants of each state.

elements.content: On the other hand, the bromido–chlorido mixed-halogenido complexes, derived from parent complexes not structurally isomorphous, produce crystals that are isomorphous to those of the bromido complex at chlorido molar fractions smaller than 0.4 and to those of the chlorido complex at contents larger than 0.6. The complexes isomorphous to the bromido complex do not display emission from the 3CT state characteristic of the chlorido sites, although such complexes do contain chlorido ligands. In the case of the iodido–chlorido mixed complexes, crystals isomorphous to those of the iodido complex were obtained even at a chlorido molar fraction of 0.6, and they do not show the 3CT band characteristic of chlorido sites but the 3π–π*-band characteristic of the iodido complex. These features of mixed-halogenido complexes demonstrate that a halogenido ligand can substitute the site for other halogenido ligands even in the different type structures because of being monatomic ligands with similar coordination properties. Thus, the {Ag2Cl2(PPh3)2(bpy)} unit can show “nonintrinsic” photophysical properties characteristic of such an unusual structure, unlike the homochlorido complex in the present systems. The modification of physical properties by formation of a mixed phase is widely utilized in solid-state compounds, such as alloys and metal oxides, and has recently also been applied to various coordination polymers for control of their properties, such as gas absorption, conductivity, color emission, and catalytic activity. Together with the antenna effect we have previously reported, the synthesis of mixed-coordination polymers is a powerful tool to produce compounds with desirable photophysical properties.

elements.content:
As shown in Figure S2, the shape of the emission bands did not show dependence upon excitation wavelengths, supporting that the dual emission of chlorido complex is not caused by impurities.

The emission lifetimes of the complexes are sensitive to their crystallinity. Because of the limitation of our measurement system, the measurements with cryostats required crushing the crystals, which resulted in the non-single-exponential decays. The emission decays were fitted with biexponential functions and averaged lifetimes, (A 1·τ1 2 + A 2·τ2 2)/(A 1·τ1 + A 2·τ2), were used to discuss their dependence upon temperatures.

elements.content: Although H-28, which is mainly composed of π-orbitals of bpy, is far more stable than the HOMO and other OMOs (H-1–H-10) located on the {Ag2X2} cores, the 3π–π*-state is located fairly close to T1 in energy. The larger stabilization of the 3π–π*-state than the HOMO–LUMO and the OMO-LUMO states can be attributed to its compact electron distribution. In a triplet state, the electron–electron repulsion is smaller than in the corresponding singlet state, and the decrease of the electron–electron repulsion is more effective in a smaller orbital. Indeed, the S1 and T1 of 3–I, both of them corresponding to the HOMO–LUMO transition with wide electron distribution, have substantially similar energies of 2.789 eV (445 nm) and 2.771 eV (447 nm), respectively (Table S18).

elements.content: In both models, the highest bpy π-orbital is divided into H-26, H-27, and H-28 (Tables S21 and S25 and Figure S7). The sum of the components of these orbitals show that they are mainly composed of three orbitals, namely, the bpy π-orbital (97 of 300%), π-orbital of the Ph ring (85 of 300%), and silver 5d-orbital (78 of 300%). If the energy of π of Ph and Ag 5d are supposed to be intact, the energy change of the bpy π-orbital is roughly estimated by the difference of the sum of the energies of these orbitals, which are −22.705 eV in 3–Cl and −22.673 eV in 4–Cl, also leading to the destabilization by 0.03 eV in 4–Cl.
elements.clean_text: In both models, the highest bpy π-orbital is divided into H-26, H-27, and H-28 (Tables S21 and S25 and Figure S7). The sum of the components of these orbitals show that they are mainly composed of three orbitals, namely, the bpy π-orbital (97 of 300%), π-orbital of the Ph ring (85 of 300%), and silver 5d-orbital (78 of 300%). If the energy of π of Ph and Ag 5d are supposed to be intact, the energy change of the bpy π-orbital is roughly estimated by the difference of the sum of the energies of these orbitals, which are -22.705 eV in 3-Cl and -22.673 eV in 4-Cl, also leading to the destabilization by 0.03 eV in 4-Cl.

AgCl (4.7 mg, 0.033 mmol) and PPh3 (17.5 mg, 0.066 mmol) were dissolved in a solvent mixture of CH2Cl2/DMF (2 mL, 2 mL), to which was added a CH3CN solution of bpy (1.0 mL, 18 mg, 0.12 mmol). After a few days, the solution afforded colorless crystals. Yield: 5.4 mg (17%). Anal. calcd for [{Ag2Cl2(PPh3)2}­(bpy)] n : C, 57.11; H, 3.96; N, 2.90. Found: C, 56.87; H, 4.01; N, 2.85.

[{Ag<sub>2</sub>(I<sub>(1–<italic>x</italic>)</sub>Br<sub> <italic>x</italic> </sub>)<sub>2</sub>(PPh<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>}­(μ-bpy)]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<italic>x</italic> = 0.1, 0.3, 0.5, 0.7, 0.9)

A CH3CN/DMF (1:4) mixed solution containing AgI (1.10 mmol/L) and PPh3 (2.21 mmol/L) was prepared. A CH3CN/DMF (1:4) mixed solution containing AgBr (1.66 mmol/L) and PPh3 (3.31 mmol/L) was prepared. From two stock solutions, specific amounts were taken and mixed as shown in Table S1, to make the total amount of AgX 0.033 mmol and the Br fraction 0.1, 0.3, 0.5, 0.7, and 0.9 in each solution. To each solution was added a CH3CN solution of bpy (0.115 mmol, 1.0 mL). After a few days, the solution afforded homogeneous colorless crystals. The molar fraction of Br (x) in the compound was determined by elemental analysis.

The molar fraction of Cl (x) in the compound was determined by elemental analysis.

cln_elements.content:
As shown in , the iodido and bromido complexes show a similar-energy band at ∼450 nm with lifetimes of 22 and 307 μs, respectively.

The related copper­(I) complexes [Cu2X2(PPh3)2(bpy)] have been reported to display a broad band at ∼530 nm. The bands of the copper­(I) complexes have been assigned to charge-transfer (CT) transitions from the {Cu2X2} core to the bpy ligand. The coincidence of emission bands for the iodido and bromido silver­(I) complexes and clear progression observed at lower temperatures indicate that the emission bands are assignable to ligand-centered transitions ().
cln_elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Properties of Homohalogenido Complexes

As shown in , the iodido and bromido complexes show a similar-energy band at ~450 nm with lifetimes of 22 and 307 μs, respectively.

The related copper(I) complexes [Cu2X2(PPh3)2(bpy)] have been reported to display a broad band at ~530 nm. The bands of the copper(I) complexes have been assigned to charge-transfer (CT) transitions from the {Cu2X2} core to the bpy ligand. The coincidence of emission bands for the iodido and bromido silver(I) complexes and clear progression observed at lower temperatures indicate that the emission bands are assignable to ligand-centered transitions ().

peak spectrum.condition: charge-transfer (CT) transitions from the {Cu2X2} core to the bpy ligand
